speech.text: Ay, but not enough.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: And thereof came it that the man was mad. The venom clamours of a jealous woman Poisons more deadly than a mad dog's tooth. It seems his sleeps were hinder'd by thy railing, And therefore comes it that his head is light. Thou say'st his meat was sauced with thy upbraidings: Unquiet meals make ill digestions; Thereof the raging fire of fever bred; And what's a fever but a fit of madness? Thou say'st his sports were hinderd by thy brawls: Sweet recreation barr'd, what doth ensue But moody and dull melancholy, Kinsman to grim and comfortless despair, And at her heels a huge infectious troop Of pale distemperatures and foes to life? In food, in sport and life-preserving rest To be disturb'd, would mad or man or beast: The consequence is then thy jealous fits Have scared thy husband from the use of wits.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: She never reprehended him but mildly, When he demean'd himself rough, rude and wildly. Why bear you these rebukes and answer not?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: She did betray me to my own reproof. Good people enter and lay hold on him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: No, not a creature enters in my house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Then let your servants bring my husband forth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Neither: he took this place for sanctuary, And it shall privilege him from your hands Till I have brought him to his wits again, Or lose my labour in assaying it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: I will attend my husband, be his nurse, Diet his sickness, for it is my office, And will have no attorney but myself; And therefore let me have him home with me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Be patient; for I will not let him stir Till I have used the approved means I have, With wholesome syrups, drugs and holy prayers, To make of him a formal man again: It is a branch and parcel of mine oath, A charitable duty of my order. Therefore depart and leave him here with me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: I will not hence and leave my husband here: And ill it doth beseem your holiness To separate the husband and the wife.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Be quiet and depart: thou shalt not have him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Complain unto the duke of this indignity.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Come, go: I will fall prostrate at his feet And never rise until my tears and prayers Have won his grace to come in person hither And take perforce my husband from the abbess.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: By this, I think, the dial points at five: Anon, I'm sure, the duke himself in person Comes this way to the melancholy vale, The place of death and sorry execution, Behind the ditches of the abbey here.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Upon what cause?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: To see a reverend Syracusian merchant, Who put unluckily into this bay Against the laws and statutes of this town, Beheaded publicly for his offence.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: See where they come: we will behold his death.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Kneel to the duke before he pass the abbey.

speech.stagedir: Enter DUKE SOLINUS, attended; AEGEON bareheaded; with the Headsman and other Officers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Yet once again proclaim it publicly, If any friend will pay the sum for him, He shall not die; so much we tender him.

speech.stagedir: Enter DUKE SOLINUS, attended; AEGEON bareheaded; with the Headsman and other Officers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Justice, most sacred duke, against the abbess!

speech.stagedir: Enter DUKE SOLINUS, attended; AEGEON bareheaded; with the Headsman and other Officers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: She is a virtuous and a reverend lady: It cannot be that she hath done thee wrong.

speech.stagedir: Enter DUKE SOLINUS, attended; AEGEON bareheaded; with the Headsman and other Officers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: May it please your grace, Antipholus, my husband, Whom I made lord of me and all I had, At your important letters,--this ill day A most outrageous fit of madness took him; That desperately he hurried through the street, With him his bondman, all as mad as he-- Doing displeasure to the citizens By rushing in their houses, bearing thence Rings, jewels, any thing his rage did like. Once did I get him bound and sent him home, Whilst to take order for the wrongs I went, That here and there his fury had committed. Anon, I wot not by what strong escape, He broke from those that had the guard of him; And with his mad attendant and himself, Each one with ireful passion, with drawn swords, Met us again and madly bent on us, Chased us away; till, raising of more aid, We came again to bind them. Then they fled Into this abbey, whither we pursued them: And here the abbess shuts the gates on us And will not suffer us to fetch him out, Nor send him forth that we may bear him hence. Therefore, most gracious duke, with thy command Let him be brought forth and borne hence for help.

speech.stagedir: Enter DUKE SOLINUS, attended; AEGEON bareheaded; with the Headsman and other Officers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Long since thy husband served me in my wars, And I to thee engaged a prince's word, When thou didst make him master of thy bed, To do him all the grace and good I could. Go, some of you, knock at the abbey-gate And bid the lady abbess come to me. I will determine this before I stir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: O mistress, mistress, shift and save yourself! My master and his man are both broke loose, Beaten the maids a-row and bound the doctor Whose beard they have singed off with brands of fire; And ever, as it blazed, they threw on him Great pails of puddled mire to quench the hair: My master preaches patience to him and the while His man with scissors nicks him like a fool, And sure, unless you send some present help, Between them they will kill the conjurer.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Peace, fool! thy master and his man are here, And that is false thou dost report to us.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Mistress, upon my life, I tell you true; I have not breathed almost since I did see it. He cries for you, and vows, if he can take you, To scorch your face and to disfigure you. Hark, hark! I hear him, mistress. fly, be gone!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Come, stand by me; fear nothing. Guard with halberds!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Ay me, it is my husband! Witness you, That he is borne about invisible: Even now we housed him in the abbey here; And now he's there, past thought of human reason.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Justice, most gracious duke, O, grant me justice! Even for the service that long since I did thee, When I bestrid thee in the wars and took Deep scars to save thy life; even for the blood That then I lost for thee, now grant me justice.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Unless the fear of death doth make me dote, I see my son Antipholus and Dromio.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Justice, sweet prince, against that woman there! She whom thou gavest to me to be my wife, That hath abused and dishonour'd me Even in the strength and height of injury! Beyond imagination is the wrong That she this day hath shameless thrown on me.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Discover how, and thou shalt find me just.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: This day, great duke, she shut the doors upon me, While she with harlots feasted in my house.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: A grievous fault! Say, woman, didst thou so?

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: No, my good lord: myself, he and my sister To-day did dine together. So befall my soul As this is false he burdens me withal!

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Ne'er may I look on day, nor sleep on night, But she tells to your highness simple truth!

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: O perjured woman! They are both forsworn: In this the madman justly chargeth them.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: My liege, I am advised what I say, Neither disturbed with the effect of wine, Nor heady-rash, provoked with raging ire, Albeit my wrongs might make one wiser mad. This woman lock'd me out this day from dinner: That goldsmith there, were he not pack'd with her, Could witness it, for he was with me then; Who parted with me to go fetch a chain, Promising to bring it to the Porpentine, Where Balthazar and I did dine together. Our dinner done, and he not coming thither, I went to seek him: in the street I met him And in his company that gentleman. There did this perjured goldsmith swear me down That I this day of him received the chain, Which, God he knows, I saw not: for the which He did arrest me with an officer. I did obey, and sent my peasant home For certain ducats: he with none return'd Then fairly I bespoke the officer To go in person with me to my house. By the way we met My wife, her sister, and a rabble more Of vile confederates. Along with them They brought one Pinch, a hungry lean-faced villain, A mere anatomy, a mountebank, A threadbare juggler and a fortune-teller, A needy, hollow-eyed, sharp-looking wretch, A dead-looking man: this pernicious slave, Forsooth, took on him as a conjurer, And, gazing in mine eyes, feeling my pulse, And with no face, as 'twere, outfacing me, Cries out, I was possess'd. Then all together They fell upon me, bound me, bore me thence And in a dark and dankish vault at home There left me and my man, both bound together; Till, gnawing with my teeth my bonds in sunder, I gain'd my freedom, and immediately Ran hither to your grace; whom I beseech To give me ample satisfaction For these deep shames and great indignities.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: My lord, in truth, thus far I witness with him, That he dined not at home, but was lock'd out.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: But had he such a chain of thee or no?

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: He had, my lord: and when he ran in here, These people saw the chain about his neck.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Besides, I will be sworn these ears of mine Heard you confess you had the chain of him After you first forswore it on the mart: And thereupon I drew my sword on you; And then you fled into this abbey here, From whence, I think, you are come by miracle.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: I never came within these abbey-walls, Nor ever didst thou draw thy sword on me: I never saw the chain, so help me Heaven! And this is false you burden me withal.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Why, what an intricate impeach is this! I think you all have drunk of Circe's cup. If here you housed him, here he would have been; If he were mad, he would not plead so coldly: You say he dined at home; the goldsmith here Denies that saying. Sirrah, what say you?

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Sir, he dined with her there, at the Porpentine.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: He did, and from my finger snatch'd that ring.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: 'Tis true, my liege; this ring I had of her.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Saw'st thou him enter at the abbey here?

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: As sure, my liege, as I do see your grace.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Ephesus and DROMIO of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Why, this is strange. Go call the abbess hither. I think you are all mated or stark mad.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Most mighty duke, vouchsafe me speak a word: Haply I see a friend will save my life And pay the sum that may deliver me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Speak freely, Syracusian, what thou wilt.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Is not your name, sir, call'd Antipholus? And is not that your bondman, Dromio?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Within this hour I was his bondman sir, But he, I thank him, gnaw'd in two my cords: Now am I Dromio and his man unbound.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: I am sure you both of you remember me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Why look you strange on me? you know me well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: O, grief hath changed me since you saw me last, And careful hours with time's deformed hand Have written strange defeatures in my face: But tell me yet, dost thou not know my voice?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Neither.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Dromio, nor thou?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: No, trust me, sir, nor I.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: I am sure thou dost.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Ay, sir, but I am sure I do not; and whatsoever a man denies, you are now bound to believe him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Not know my voice! O time's extremity, Hast thou so crack'd and splitted my poor tongue In seven short years, that here my only son Knows not my feeble key of untuned cares? Though now this grained face of mine be hid In sap-consuming winter's drizzled snow, And all the conduits of my blood froze up, Yet hath my night of life some memory, My wasting lamps some fading glimmer left, My dull deaf ears a little use to hear: All these old witnesses--I cannot err-- Tell me thou art my son Antipholus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: I never saw my father in my life.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: But seven years since, in Syracusa, boy, Thou know'st we parted: but perhaps, my son, Thou shamest to acknowledge me in misery.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: The duke and all that know me in the city Can witness with me that it is not so I ne'er saw Syracusa in my life.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: I tell thee, Syracusian, twenty years Have I been patron to Antipholus, During which time he ne'er saw Syracusa: I see thy age and dangers make thee dote.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter AEMILIA, with ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse and DROMIO of Syracuse
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Most mighty duke, behold a man much wrong'd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: I see two husbands, or mine eyes deceive me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: I, sir, am Dromio; command him away.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: I, sir, am Dromio; pray, let me stay.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: AEgeon art thou not? or else his ghost?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: O, my old master! who hath bound him here?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Whoever bound him, I will loose his bonds And gain a husband by his liberty. Speak, old AEgeon, if thou be'st the man That hadst a wife once call'd AEmilia That bore thee at a burden two fair sons: O, if thou be'st the same AEgeon, speak, And speak unto the same AEmilia!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: If I dream not, thou art AEmilia: If thou art she, tell me where is that son That floated with thee on the fatal raft?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: By men of Epidamnum he and I And the twin Dromio all were taken up; But by and by rude fishermen of Corinth By force took Dromio and my son from them And me they left with those of Epidamnum. What then became of them I cannot tell I to this fortune that you see me in.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Why, here begins his morning story right; These two Antipholuses, these two so like, And these two Dromios, one in semblance,-- Besides her urging of her wreck at sea,-- These are the parents to these children, Which accidentally are met together. Antipholus, thou camest from Corinth first?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: No, sir, not I; I came from Syracuse.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Stay, stand apart; I know not which is which.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: I came from Corinth, my most gracious lord,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: And I with him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Brought to this town by that most famous warrior, Duke Menaphon, your most renowned uncle.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Which of you two did dine with me to-day?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: I, gentle mistress.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: And are not you my husband?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: No; I say nay to that.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: And so do I; yet did she call me so: And this fair gentlewoman, her sister here, Did call me brother. What I told you then, I hope I shall have leisure to make good; If this be not a dream I see and hear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: That is the chain, sir, which you had of me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: I think it be, sir; I deny it not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: And you, sir, for this chain arrested me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: I think I did, sir; I deny it not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: I sent you money, sir, to be your bail, By Dromio; but I think he brought it not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: No, none by me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: This purse of ducats I received from you, And Dromio, my man, did bring them me. I see we still did meet each other's man, And I was ta'en for him, and he for me, And thereupon these errors are arose.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: These ducats pawn I for my father here.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: It shall not need; thy father hath his life.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Sir, I must have that diamond from you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: There, take it; and much thanks for my good cheer.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Renowned duke, vouchsafe to take the pains To go with us into the abbey here And hear at large discoursed all our fortunes: And all that are assembled in this place, That by this sympathized one day's error Have suffer'd wrong, go keep us company, And we shall make full satisfaction. Thirty-three years have I but gone in travail Of you, my sons; and till this present hour My heavy burden ne'er delivered. The duke, my husband and my children both, And you the calendars of their nativity, Go to a gossips' feast and go with me; After so long grief, such festivity!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: With all my heart, I'll gossip at this feast.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but Antipholus of Syracuse, Antipholus of Ephesus, Dromio of Syracuse and Dromio of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Master, shall I fetch your stuff from shipboard?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but Antipholus of Syracuse, Antipholus of Ephesus, Dromio of Syracuse and Dromio of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Dromio, what stuff of mine hast thou embark'd?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but Antipholus of Syracuse, Antipholus of Ephesus, Dromio of Syracuse and Dromio of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Your goods that lay at host, sir, in the Centaur.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but Antipholus of Syracuse, Antipholus of Ephesus, Dromio of Syracuse and Dromio of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: He speaks to me. I am your master, Dromio: Come, go with us; we'll look to that anon: Embrace thy brother there; rejoice with him.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Antipholus of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: There is a fat friend at your master's house, That kitchen'd me for you to-day at dinner: She now shall be my sister, not my wife.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Antipholus of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Methinks you are my glass, and not my brother: I see by you I am a sweet-faced youth. Will you walk in to see their gossiping?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Antipholus of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: Not I, sir; you are my elder.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Antipholus of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: That's a question: how shall we try it?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Antipholus of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
speech.text: We'll draw cuts for the senior: till then lead thou first.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt Antipholus of Syracuse and Antipholus of Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A street before a Priory.
